The airconditioning cannot be controlled by temperature - only fan speed. It was really stuffy in the room and I woke up on my snooker table like bed bathed in perspiration. I have stayed here many times and the AC problem is immensely irritating as it is NEVER effective. There were hairs in the bathtub, and the satin coverlets were dirty. Room service was prompt, but the dish I ordered was not what I was expecting. I think this was my fault rather than theirs, but the items were not charged and there was no fuss either - so kudos for that. All rooms have balconies, but the sliding door doesn't fit well, resulting in traffic noise that requires earplugs. In summary; Rooms: Depressing, grubby, stuffy, beds like pool tables, noisy. Why bother? Better at a youth hostel. I bet the ones in Singapore are clean and well run. The South tower however, is superb, lovely beds, icy air-con, sparking bathrooms, Bose sound systems, flat screen TV, effective sound insulation - I loved staying there. On the Fairmont website there is no way of telling which tower you are in. Honestly, to stay in the North Tower is to waste your money. My company put me up here and I have had enough of it.

Reviews.Title: “Adequate...”
Reviews.Author: Waterwise
Reviews.Content: We spent 5 nights at the Fairmont. We were upgraded from a ‘Deluxe’ room to an ‘Executive’ Room on the 22nd Floor. This entitled us to enjoy the ‘Executive Club’, a lounge offering all-day snacks and free cocktails in the evening- no kids allowed. We have 2 young ones so no value to us. There is also a small gym up there for ‘Executive’ guests. The room was fine- modern décor, surround sound, flat screen TV, electric curtains, etc.. Nice spacious modern bathroom, king-size shower. We think it a waste to have all linen changed every day but there is really no option but to have ones towels replaced every day as nowhere to hang them up, simply a large basket to throw them in! We had booked a room with king-size bed (and cot) but were given 2 doubles. Best they could do was push doubles together and make up bed with king-size linen. Coffee/tea making facilities- there is a smart expresso machine. If, like us, you drink tea, take your tea bags with you. The 2 provided don’t go far! The cups are designed for an expresso from the coffee maker so you could just about use one bag for 2 cups (there is all-day coffee and tea from the ‘Executive Club’ (if you don’t have kids!)). With our air con set to its lowest speed and highest temperature (30degC) we were freezing. The ‘engineer’ was assigned to fix this. The following night with the air con set at its highest speed and lowest temperature (20degC) we were in a sauna bath. The following day the ‘engineer’ returned- we then returned to the arctic and simply decided to ‘rug-up’. At least we could open the door on to the little balcony- something you cannot often do in high-rise hotels. Our package included breakfast. Breakfast is standard hotel buffet style. Seems like hotels try to outdo each other for the most obscure dishes for breakfast- you look at half this stuff and wonder just WHO would want THAT for breakfast. If you came down from Mars there’d be something you’d like. No particular reflection on this hotel in particular (there almost ALL the same) but is anyone else out there sick of the breakfast offering of leather for bacon and sausages that look more like they’re boiled than grilled or fried? Whilst I’m about it has anyone ever met one of those motorised toaster machines that makes a piece of toast (as opposed to warmed bread) in one ‘pass’? Singapore hotels cater for a very cosmopolitan clientele including many UK/American & Australasian clients. Amongst the okra sambal, the sio mai, chicken curry, steamed pork buns, chick pea curry and miso soup there was nothing as simple as baked beans in tomato sauce. On one morning only were there some soggy little hash browns. Amongst the salads, dozens of cold meats and cheeses and fruits I had never even seen before there were no mushrooms sautéed, grilled or cooked by any means whatsoever. Take the tea… the coffee is well and truly stewed. The hotel pool on the 8th floor is great and good for kids including our littlies. There is a separate kids’ pool. The concierge was helpful & forthcoming on tourist info except when we sought info on the harbour cruise. He sent us off to the Esplanade (20 minute walk) which is where he had advised the boats left from. With 2 little kids in tow we trudged the length of the Esplanade. We had another 20 minute walk to the ‘merlion’ fountain to find where the boats actually DO leave from. Whilst the room was tidy and new some parts of the hotel look a little jaded. The furniture in the ‘lounge’ off reception are reminiscent of grandad’s favourite old chair you wish he’d get rid of. One benefit of staying here is that the hotel is part of Raffles Square (with THE Raffles across the road) which is full of ritzy stores and restaurants aplenty). Reception is friendly and helpful, the service is generally very attentive. The hotel is unremarkable, a not untypical modern and rather soulless Singapore Hotel-not much not to criticise it for, not much to recommend it for either.

Reviews.Title: “Quality Hotel & Service”
Reviews.Author: Pendle44
Reviews.Content: Stopped fot 7 nights at end of February. Overall excellent place to stay. Not cheap but represented value for money. Opted to pay for an upgrade to South Tower room with tropical raindrop shower - well worth it. Superb room and bathroom. Turn down service adding fresh towels twice a day added to the quality. Great location. Could not fault it. Special mention for the hotel doorman, wonderful warm friendly welcome each time we returned to the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Good Location”
Reviews.Author: Ellana
Reviews.Content: We stayed in a standard room at corporate rates. The room was elegant and well appointed however the bathroom was in need of refurbishment, particularly the tiles. We had a balcony overlooking a large courtyard garden but was unable to use it as the air conditioning unit from the adjoining shopping centre was far too noisy. The staff gave great service but there was no tour desk and it was really geared around business guests rather than tourists.

Reviews.Title: “NIce Amenities and Pool Area”
Reviews.Author: splatnz
Reviews.Content: Just checking-out of this hotel at the moment and thought I'd take a minute to write a review... Likes - Great bathroom amenities from - Nice sunny pool area with two large pools - On top of the Raffles Plaza shopping centre - You can charge your room when dining at the Swissotel and Raffles hotels next door Dislikes - Very small rooms for the price - Rooms could do with a makeover (eg old carpet etc) - Some of the Fairmont President's Club benefits unavailable (eg Aveda Travel Kits) - Fairly average housekeeping (eg replacement shampoo and soap etc just thrown onto the bathroom bench top) Overall Probably overpriced for what it is, if you get a good deal I'd recommend it though. Staff are very friendly though especially Raj at the President's Club desk and the location is good with an MRT station just downstairs and Suntec city a 5min walk away.

Reviews.Title: “good for business”
Reviews.Author: manarak
Reviews.Content: I stayed a week on corporate rate at the fairmont south tower in a standard room in early february. what to say... let's start with possible improvements: - while about 10000 wireless access points in Singapore provide FREE internet access, it is high time that hotels do the same. Maybe they could limit the speed of the free access to 512kbps or something, but asking for more than 20SGD a day for that kind of commodity is not acceptable. - cleanliness: the room itself was quite nice, but it was not very clean. usually i am not very sensible to a little dust here and there, but the cleanliness of that room was sub-standard. for example, there was a lot of dust under the TV commode and it seemed that a guest had a bottle of coke or another sticky beverage explode on the table. the table itself had been cleaned, but the lamp and other parts of furniture were still dirty, as well as the floor where that happened (sticky dried-up drops). also in the bathroom, i would find a long dark hair everyday in the middle of the floor after room cleaning. mold between tiles in the bathroom is not much of a hygiene problem, but it would just look nicer if it was regularly bleached out (a few chlorine every 3-4 months could take care of that problem) the room cleaning staff is not thorough. additionally to finding dust and sticky stains in some places, I found two DVDs hidden by another guest under the bose radio. These were bad-quality porn DVDs, so I left them there. - room service/equipment: the staff should focus on better attention to detail: the remote command of the bose radio was missing the battery and therefore didn't work. - irritating: when you call a lift and briefly press the button, it will light up, but can deactivate if you are too quick. that happened a few times, and was quite irritating, especially because the button lit up, so i thought the life was coming... - while the bad's mattress was ok, I wasn't too satisfied with the pillows, which are apparently filled with a synthetic foam, which caused me to sweat. now the positive: - my request for a non-smoker king size room was granted without trouble. - the staff was quite friendly. - the hotel is situated right next to the historic raffles, and on top a shopping mall and above the MRT (underground) station city hall. - there are direct entrances from levels 2 and 3 of the mall into the elevators, so it is very convenient for getting quickly to the room from the mall without having to pass the lobby. - if you have to check out late, they can give you access to a complementary guest suite (no bed) to wait on your plane. - 2 bottles of water are replaced every day - i will not post a list of everything that worked as expected, you can assume the rest of standard services was provided and working well. Overall, the Fairmont was not bad to stay in for business, but I feel the rate was too high (even the corporate one) for the delivered quality. Therefore, the Fairmont gets a rating of 3 from me.

Reviews.Title: “beautiful, SAFE Singapore”
Reviews.Author: wendy1461
Reviews.Content: The Fairmont has again lived up to its name. I have spent time in Canada staying at Fairmonts in 2004 and this one in Asia is no different. Neat, spotless, modern rooms with all amenites that you would expect from a 5 star hotel. Staff in the whole of the hotel are sweet and nothing is a problem for them. The hotel is above a shopping plaza which includes a supermarket and for those who love shopping, just step out of the foyer and there you go SHOPS..GO GIRLS!!! The hotel is located next to Raffles and you must go to the Long Bar for a Singapore Sling just for the experience. The hotel is just above the MRT which is a cheap way to get around the city, maximum s$1.80 for a one way trip. Orchard road is great for shopping, but I loved Little India, Kampong Glam & China Town. Eating is very cheap especially when you eat where the locals eat. Newton Circus is a must specialising in seafood. The locals are in a league of their own...the nicest, friendliest people on the planet who will help you even if you kind of look lost!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Great location, decent hotel, shame about the room cleaning (or lack of it)”
Reviews.Author: adls
Reviews.Content: We stayed here on a 4-day family holiday with our baby. We had previously stayed at the Swissotel the Stamford which is actually in the same hotel-shopping mall complex as the Fairmont. We liked the Swissotel for its great location, and decided to stay at the Fairmont this time because we had a better deal for it on Expedia and it was essentially the same location. The Fairmont is quite a businessman’s hotel: it’s smart, clean and efficient – but somehow lacks character and charisma. The building, lobby, elevators and rooms are all modern, clean, relatively spacious, but you don’t get much of a sense of occasion or opulence. There’s nothing grand or magnificent about the décor, just functionality. In that sense, I would say this is better suited for those in suits, and maybe less so for those expecting a romantic or exotic holiday. The room was quite large by Asian hotel standards. There was room enough for a cot for baby to be moved in (at no extra cost) and yet leave absolutely plenty of room for all 3 of us (mainly baby) to run around. And the cot was not a flimsy little crib, but a large proper baby’s bed with baby blankets and even a gift soft toy – nice touch. The furniture was again functional rather than grand or elegant, but at least the chairs were comfortable. The bed was definitely on the firm side – which I personally like, but which may probably not be to everyone’s tastes. The pillows were agreeably large and long, but they were too soft and shapeless and failed to give good support. I appreciated the cleanliness, but the room did show some wear and tear in places: the cold water faucet leaked a little when turned on, and the carpet was well worn down in the middle of the room (even patched over in one place). The service at the front door is excellent. The porters are exceptionally warm and courteous, and instantly made us feel welcome as we stepped out of the taxi from the airport. Check-in was efficient and reasonably friendly too. Throughout our stay, I was also impressed with being greeted by name every time I called down to the front desk (or ‘On-call Valet’ as they like to call it). Unfortunately, the good service did not extend to the room cleaners. We stayed for 4-days/3-nights. During that time, we only had our room cleaned ONCE. On one day, we were out almost all morning but came back to the room briefly at around 2pm to get a change of clothes (Singapore is a hot, humid country). The room was not cleaned all morning. We left promptly after changing and did not return until after dinner. But when we got back, not only had the room still not been cleaned, but we got a little note under our door saying that it wasn’t cleaned because we had a ‘Do Not Disturb’ sign on the door for the brief period while we were changing. After retiring to our room exhausted after a day out with baby, the last thing we wanted to do was vacate the room again at night while we called the cleaners back for cleaning (assuming anyone was still around to clean after 5pm !). Altogether we received this irresponsible little card on TWO days during our stay, suggesting it was OUR fault that the room wasn’t cleaned. This is unacceptable. Why can’t hotels like this just get their act together and clean the room quickly during the day? Is it unreasonable to expect that at a world class hotel, if the cleaner finds your room occupied when she comes round then she will check again later a second or third time until finally each room on her floor is cleaned? Since when has it become OK to just see a ‘Do Not Disturb’ sign once and assume the room cannot be cleaned at any other time of the day? Couldn’t someone simply have politely phoned us in the room to ask when would be a good time for them to clean the room? Sadly, the Fairmont is not the only hotel I’ve stayed in recently to suffer from this lazy attitude towards room cleaning – but I really would’ve expected better from a decent hotel in a country like Singapore. Having an uncleaned room for half our stay certainly spoiled our stay a fair bit. We didn’t have breakfast in our package. If you like eating, you don’t come to Singapore for bacon and eggs ! Downstairs in the Raffles City Mall alone, you can find a great variety of eateries. Try Kaya Toast, Singapore-style soft boiled eggs, and Kopi-O for a proper local breakfast. The Mall is also directly connected via an underground ‘city’ to the MRT station and nearby attractions like the Esplanade and Suntec City. Raffles Hotel (home of the Singapore Sling), Chijmes, the old civic center are all literally just across the street. Orchard Road or Chinatown are both just a couple of stops away on the MRT. This convenience of location is exactly what we loved about the Swissotel on our previous trip, and what makes staying here at the Fairmont this time brilliant. With our baby along this time, we really appreciated having a supermarket and some drug stores downstairs so that we could buy all the usual baby products (formula milk, diapers etc) instead of having to carry huge amounts on the flight. We didn’t use the hotel’s facilities much. We were too busy seeing Singapore, tasting its excellent food, visiting the world-famous Zoo, shopping on Orchard Road and so on to bother with the swimming pool etc (we didn’t even bother finding out where the pool was). If you want to enjoy a hotel like a resort, the Fairmont probably isn’t the place for you. If you want a hotel as a convenient base for you to see this remarkable island, then I would recommend this hotel (or the Swissotel) – with the condition that they sort out their room cleaning service. There was a cable internet connection in the room, but there was a charge. I usually rely heavily on the internet during my trips, but as this was a purely family holiday and the charge looked rather steep, I resisted the urge to use this service on this trip.
